data.title: The Khruanghbin effect: The rise in popularity of easy listening music among youth
data.meta_description: There's a growing popularity of mood music among youth in America. It's a stark contrast to what they were listening to a couple decades ago.

While I don't claim to be an expert music critic, I enjoy seeking out good, new bands and artists and I like to share my discoveries with others who appreciate good music as well.

Before they were big, Khruangbin was one such gem. This Houston-based trio's music defies easy categorization. At its core, Khruangbin blends diverse influences, including Southeast Asian and Middle Eastern rhythms, soulful melodies, and jazz-infused instrumentation. Their signature sound, characterized by ethereal guitar riffs and groovy bass lines, delivers a unique blend of nostalgia and innovation.

Discovering Khruangbin

I discovered Khruangbin about five years ago, at a time when their sonic landscapes stood out against the backdrop of mainstream music. Since then, numerous artists have attempted to emulate their style, yet none have achieved the same level of success.

As a guitar player and a seasoned purveyer of genre-bending music, I find that Khruangbin's sound hits on all the right notes. Their music, soothing yet exotic, feels simultaneously timeless and contemporary. Their beats groove so effortlessly, a testament to the drummer's precision that rivals the most of my watches.

Reflecting on their sound, I wondered: would Khruangbin have thrived in the late 90s and early 00s music landscape dominated by alternative, punk, grunge, and rap? Maybe. But not among the youth of that era. It would have found its success among the easy listening fans, which my parents were.

Mood music appealing to younger audiences

What strikes me as interesting is how much appeal the mood music genre, including Khruangbin, appeals to the youth of today. My teenage son occasionally introduces me to new bands of in the mood music genre that are quite popular among his friends and peers.

This underscores a broader shift in cultural perceptions and generational tastes and preferences. For content strategists and marketers, it's a compelling reminder to stop and reevaluate our understanding of young audiences.

So, don't be surprised when you discover that your younger co-workers' musical tastes are more Perry Como than Rivers Cuomo.
